title: How we can use 360 Video, Binaural Audio, VR and Pokemon Go to tell new stories
notes:
How we can use 360 Video, Binaural Audio, VR and Pokemon Go to tell new stories

We’ll set up a number of activities to experience the very latest immersive stories. We’ll discuss what works, what doesn’t and how we could improve these experiences. We’ll talk about demographics, user bases and what’s possible and how. In the second half of the session we’ll take some time to build our own 360 video and binaural audio of the Mozilla Festival and publish it online for people to experience.

Intro

THE BIG QUESTIONS

What are the capabilities of immersive technologies?

What stories can we tell with all this amazing technology?

How do we make our stories and ideas real?

What's open and what's not?


Structure:
    
Given the amount of time we have and given that a lot of the demos can only be experienced by one person at a time -  suggest we interleave group work with pauses to try out and reflect on the demos. We can break out into groups to try out the various demos, recount the experiences, talk a little about the possibilities, then get back to sketching. Experience - talk - sketch - talk - experience - talk - sketch - talk - bake! 

At some point we'll do a live demo of recording binaural audio and 360 piece.

Lots of lovely ideas and resources to be turned into a blog post. Detail here:
    
Lifestyle section - VR Cooking - travel to the hosts kitchen to understand the timings, techniques, have a direct link  to ordering the right ingredients on amazon. History/origin of the recipe - potential for learning and bridging cultural worlds with additional information.

Climbing the O2 dome - By climbing the O2 dome the idea is to mix up AR and VR.
The point of this is to give not only a point of view standing on a place and looking around but also offering the movement (forward, backward, ...)as UX. 
The user can get the experience of moving along the route wearing an head-set device that can show information moving along (data, details on the buildings seen all around, etc..). At the same time there are some spots where a VR environment kicks in by showing - for instance - as the landscape as changed throughout the years.

VR/360 spa, live 360' streaming of sports events with the possibility to switch between views from many different actors, contextual augmented experience of reading books witgh audiobooks, nature documentaries to see how animal actors perceive the environment
